subject: Prof. Lamoreaux Comment

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Hello Jan-Baptist,

Thank you for volunteering to edit our Symposium Comments. I've attached Prof. Lamoreaux's piece, and we ask that you look over the comment for light edits. Feel free to suggest edits that help clarify the point or raise questions you might think it's worthwhile to address, but please refrain from heavy edits. The comment doesn't have to directly address Prof. Priest's book. As always, we ask that you frame all edits as humble recommendations and that you provide concrete examples of the edits you recommend wherever possible.

Please send the author your edits as comments directly in the attached word doc - saved as ""Lamoreaux Credit Nation Comment_[your initials] edits_[year.month.date]. You can address any larger feedback in your email to the professor. Cc the yjlh@yale.edu account, and give the author 10 days to address your edits from the date you email them. We ask that you send your edits no later than this Friday 10/22.


Thank you again! We are excited to have you on the team.

Best,
Paul

Paul Meosky

Yale Law School '23
paul.meosky@yale.edu
(716) 949-5106

"

rawContent:
From: Meosky, Paul
Sent: Monday, October 18, 2021 11:56 AM
To: Lemaire, Jan-Baptist <jan-baptist.lemaire@yale.edu>
Cc: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities <yjlh@yale.edu>; Antill, Gregory <gregory.antill@yale.edu>
Subject: Prof. Lamoreaux Comment 
 
Hello Jan-Baptist,

Thank you for volunteering to edit our Symposium Comments. I've attached Prof. Lamoreaux's piece, and we ask that you look over the comment for light edits. Feel free to suggest edits that help clarify the point or raise questions you might think it's worthwhile to address, but please refrain from heavy edits. The comment doesn't have to directly address Prof. Priest's book. As always, we ask that you frame all edits as humble recommendations and that you provide concrete examples of the edits you recommend wherever possible.

Please send the author your edits as comments directly in the attached word doc - saved as ""Lamoreaux Credit Nation Comment_[your initials] edits_[year.month.date]. You can address any larger feedback in your email to the professor. Cc the yjlh@yale.edu account, and give the author 10 days to address your edits from the date you email them. We ask that you send your edits no later than this Friday 10/22.


Thank you again! We are excited to have you on the team.

Best,
Paul

Paul Meosky

Yale Law School '23
paul.meosky@yale.edu
(716) 949-5106
"

Re: Credit Nation Symposium Comments - Please confirm receipt,"Paul, 

No problem at all - fully understood! I look forward to hearing from you. 

Have a great weekend. 

Warmly, 

EMB

body:
Paul (if I may),


Good evening.

I have enclosed ""Caribbean Credit Nations."" Given the deadline, I thought it best to send it to you now. Please confirm receipt.

Unfortunately, I was unable to put in the footnotes. Because I work with Lutie (which builds a pipeline of Black women who are aspiring law professors), I am involved with mooting candidates. For this reason, the last few days have been very hectic.  With apologies - I must now go again to a Lutie obligation and we will undoubtedly run late.

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration.

Best,

EMB


Eleanor Brown (202 361 5568/ 786 201 3823)

Professor of Law and International Affairs

Senior Scientist, the Rock Ethics Institute

The Pennsylvania State University,

Immediate Past Chair, Lutie Lytle Black Women Law Faculty Conference

Hello everyone,

This is just a friendly reminder to send your comments to yjlh@yale.edu by next Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. We look forward to reading your thoughts!



Best,
Paul & Greg

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

Re: Credit Nation Symposium Comments - Please confirm receipt,"Hello Prof. Brown,

I apologize for the silence, but we had some trouble rustling up editors during midterms. I'm happy to say I'll be taking your comment, and I'm excited to read it. I'll send any feedback in the next few days.

Thank you so much!
Paul

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Paul (if I may),


Good evening.

I have enclosed ""Caribbean Credit Nations."" Given the deadline, I thought it best to send it to you now. Please confirm receipt.

Unfortunately, I was unable to put in the footnotes. Because I work with Lutie (which builds a pipeline of Black women who are aspiring law professors), I am involved with mooting candidates. For this reason, the last few days have been very hectic.  With apologies - I must now go again to a Lutie obligation and we will undoubtedly run late.

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration.

Best,

EMB

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

Re: Prof. Lamoreaux Comment,"Hi Jan-Baptist,

I just wanted to check in about the Symposium edits. Would you be able to send Prof. Lamoreaux your comments by Sunday night?

Thank you for the help!
Paul

subject: Prof. Lamoreaux Comment

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Hello Jan-Baptist,

Thank you for volunteering to edit our Symposium Comments. I've attached Prof. Lamoreaux's piece, and we ask that you look over the comment for light edits. Feel free to suggest edits that help clarify the point or raise questions you might think it's worthwhile to address, but please refrain from heavy edits. The comment doesn't have to directly address Prof. Priest's book. As always, we ask that you frame all edits as humble recommendations and that you provide concrete examples of the edits you recommend wherever possible.

Please send the author your edits as comments directly in the attached word doc - saved as ""Lamoreaux Credit Nation Comment_[your initials] edits_[year.month.date]. You can address any larger feedback in your email to the professor. Cc the yjlh@yale.edu account, and give the author 10 days to address your edits from the date you email them. We ask that you send your edits no later than this Friday 10/22.


Thank you again! We are excited to have you on the team.

Best,
Paul

Paul Meosky

body:
Hi Paul and Greg,



I’ve run through this and made a few comments, but I wasn’t sure how you envisioned these responses. Prof Ellickson’s doesn’t really engage with Priest’s book at all, and I wasn’t sure whether I should make comments meant to induce such reflection, or whether the piece is acceptable standing on its own.



You’ll note that I largely limited my comments to moments where I felt Prof. Ellickson could create a clearer sense of consistency throughout the short piece. I refrained from a heavier edit, however. Please let me know if you have any questions or comments!



All my best,

Mark

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Paul (if I may),


Good evening.

I have enclosed ""Caribbean Credit Nations."" Given the deadline, I thought it best to send it to you now. Please confirm receipt.

Unfortunately, I was unable to put in the footnotes. Because I work with Lutie (which builds a pipeline of Black women who are aspiring law professors), I am involved with mooting candidates. For this reason, the last few days have been very hectic.  With apologies - I must now go again to a Lutie obligation and we will undoubtedly run late.

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration.

Best,

EMB


Eleanor Brown (202 361 5568/ 786 201 3823)

Professor of Law and International Affairs

Senior Scientist, the Rock Ethics Institute

The Pennsylvania State University,

Immediate Past Chair, Lutie Lytle Black Women Law Faculty Conference

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration. 

Best, 

EMB

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

Re: Symposium Comment for Review,"Hi Mark,

I'm so sorry for missing that email. It didn't forward to my personal email, and I'm afraid I overlooked it. Thanks for sending that out, and let us know when you have time to get involved again.

Best,
Paul

body:
Hi Mark,

Greg and I discussed your question, and we think your edits are spot-on. At Prof. Priest's request, the comments do not have to directly relate or discuss her book. We also do not want to give authors heavy edits unless absolutely necessary. Please send your edits directly to Prof. Ellickson (robert.ellickson@yale.edu) and cc the yjlh@yale.edu account. We can give Prof. Ellickson two weeks to turn around edits (i.e., edits due Friday, 10/22 if you send today).

Now that you are familiar with the type of content we are looking for, we would love to have you edit Prof. Lamoreaux's comment <https://nam12.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fdocument%2Fd%2F1AeInl9mKXgNRe6JMd9mQkeyE0cOGTzWt%2Fedit%3Fusp%3Dsharing%26ouid%3D100677056434763944886%26rtpof%3Dtrue%26sd%3Dtrue&data=04%7C01%7Cyjlh%40yale.edu%7C93dd6be0e46a41981a5a08d9926bd167%7Cdd8cbebb21394df8b4114e3e87abeb5c%7C0%7C0%7C637701814027455374%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=9vRYxXwix7ooeCkhAYhQ5WP790mhxdGOoY5VKoJ3mF8%3D&reserved=0>  as well. Feel free to send your edits directly to the professor (naomi.lamoreaux@yale.edu) and cc the yjlh@yale.edu account. She should also have two weeks to turn around edits.

body:
Hi Paul and Greg,



I’ve run through this and made a few comments, but I wasn’t sure how you envisioned these responses. Prof Ellickson’s doesn’t really engage with Priest’s book at all, and I wasn’t sure whether I should make comments meant to induce such reflection, or whether the piece is acceptable standing on its own.



You’ll note that I largely limited my comments to moments where I felt Prof. Ellickson could create a clearer sense of consistency throughout the short piece. I refrained from a heavier edit, however. Please let me know if you have any questions or comments!



All my best,

Mark





From: Meosky, Paul <paul.meosky@yale.edu>
Date: Thursday, October 7, 2021 at 8:00 AM
To: Firmani, Mark <mark.firmani@yale.edu>
Cc: Antill, Gregory <gregory.antill@yale.edu>, Yale Journal of Law and Humanities <yjlh@yale.edu>
Subject: Fw: Symposium Comment for Review

Hi Mark,



We have our first Symposium comment to edit! The comment is attached and is also located in the Google Drive here <https://nam12.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fdocument%2Fd%2F14tVBBstoKxelkacaNZIa7QHxMR70FDIP%2Fedit%3Fusp%3Dsharing%26ouid%3D100677056434763944886%26rtpof%3Dtrue%26sd%3Dtrue&data=04%7C01%7Cyjlh%40yale.edu%7C93dd6be0e46a41981a5a08d9926bd167%7Cdd8cbebb21394df8b4114e3e87abeb5c%7C0%7C0%7C637701814027455374%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=cUse9oqtQf%2BWZYDtN%2BruC%2BsZkSq%2BOt5GkEjc%2BJSq9%2Bg%3D&reserved=0> . Since these comments are so short, we don't require a formal edit letter. Rather, we'd like you to leave your comments and track changes in a word document and share your general thoughts with the author via email. body:
Hi Mark,

Greg and I discussed your question, and we think your edits are spot-on. At Prof. Priest's request, the comments do not have to directly relate or discuss her book. We also do not want to give authors heavy edits unless absolutely necessary. Please send your edits directly to Prof. Ellickson (robert.ellickson@yale.edu) and cc the yjlh@yale.edu account. We can give Prof. Ellickson two weeks to turn around edits (i.e., edits due Friday, 10/22 if you send today).

Now that you are familiar with the type of content we are looking for, we would love to have you edit Prof. Lamoreaux's comment <https://nam12.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fdocument%2Fd%2F1AeInl9mKXgNRe6JMd9mQkeyE0cOGTzWt%2Fedit%3Fusp%3Dsharing%26ouid%3D100677056434763944886%26rtpof%3Dtrue%26sd%3Dtrue&data=04%7C01%7Cyjlh%40yale.edu%7Cb3963b53d9b34a040dbd08d9926a6508%7Cdd8cbebb21394df8b4114e3e87abeb5c%7C0%7C0%7C637701807914626661%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=i4GZ%2Bxm1LRTLc7cxOUKv01XZfWeRLgd7WB%2BZAbZ2tB8%3D&reserved=0>  as well. body:
Paul (if I may),


Good evening.

I have enclosed ""Caribbean Credit Nations."" Given the deadline, I thought it best to send it to you now. Please confirm receipt.

Unfortunately, I was unable to put in the footnotes. Because I work with Lutie (which builds a pipeline of Black women who are aspiring law professors), I am involved with mooting candidates. For this reason, the last few days have been very hectic.  With apologies - I must now go again to a Lutie obligation and we will undoubtedly run late.

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration.

Best,

EMB


Eleanor Brown (202 361 5568/ 786 201 3823)

Professor of Law and International Affairs

Senior Scientist, the Rock Ethics Institute

The Pennsylvania State University,

Immediate Past Chair, Lutie Lytle Black Women Law Faculty Conference

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

From: Meosky, Paul
Sent: Tuesday, September 28, 2021 8:38 AM
To: Rose, Carol <carol.rose@yale.edu>; Stuart' 'Banner <banner@law.ucla.edu>; eub226@psu.edu <eub226@psu.edu>; Whitman, James <james.whitman@yale.edu>; Lamoreaux, Naomi <naomi.lamoreaux@yale.edu>; spincus@uchicago.edu <spincus@uchicago.edu>; laura.edwards@princeton.edu <laura.edwards@princeton.edu>; wallis@umd.edu <wallis@umd.edu>; Ellickson, Robert <robert.ellickson@yale.edu>; Witt, John <john.witt@yale.edu>; Hulsebosch@mercury.law.nyu.edu <Hulsebosch@mercury.law.nyu.edu>; KSue.Park@georgetown.edu <KSue.Park@georgetown.edu>; Zhang, Taisu <taisu.zhang@yale.edu>; harrisr@tauex.tau.ac.il <harrisr@tauex.tau.ac.il>
Cc: Antill, Gregory <gregory.antill@yale.edu>; Priest, Claire <claire.priest@yale.edu>; Yale Journal of Law and Humanities <yjlh@yale.edu>
Subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments 
 
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments. 

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

Best,
Paul

Subject: Re: Credit Nation Symposium Comments - Please confirm receipt 
 
Paul (if I may), 


Good evening.

I have enclosed ""Caribbean Credit Nations."" Given the deadline, I thought it best to send it to you now. Please confirm receipt.

Unfortunately, I was unable to put in the footnotes. Because I work with Lutie (which builds a pipeline of Black women who are aspiring law professors), I am involved with mooting candidates. For this reason, the last few days have been very hectic.  With apologies - I must now go again to a Lutie obligation and we will undoubtedly run late. 

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration. 

Best, 

EMB

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

Re: Symposium Article to Review,"Hi Claire,

That sounds like a plan! I'll accept the article and remind him about the date. I'll leave the details for you and Taisu to arrange!

Happy Friday!
Paul

subject: Re: Symposium Article to Review

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Paul,

You should know that I sent the schedule to Dan and a number of colleagues and friends yesterday, not knowing he had written that piece.



Before inviting him to take part in the conference, I’d like to touch base with Taisu and also hear back from the other panelists to see where things are.

So let’s not invite him just yet. By Monday we will have a lot more information.

I think the invitation should come from Taisu—if it is ok with you—since Taisu invited the others.



You could accept the piece now and either resend the schedule or not. We’ll be in touch with him next week if there is room on a panel.

Thank you,

Claire

Or would you like me to ask him to participate in any of the panels? I can also just ask him to RSVP directly to you, and you can discuss possibilities at that time. Please let me know what you'd prefer.



Best,

Paul

body:
Fantastic!

I was wondering who could write such an eloquent informed piece, with an emphasis on loyalists. I thought of Dan but then he tricked me with how he sighted his work in the piece. I’m proud to have him in the issue with the conference papers!

Now I’m wondering if we should include him in the author meets readers panel . . . .

Subject: Re: Symposium Article to Review



Good morning Claire,



Hooray! We'll send an acceptance letter to the author - Daniel Hulsebosch - from NYU. We would also love to invite him, and we can send him the same invitation you used earlier in the year.



In other news, our Masthead is also eager to attend, and we will send them Karen Crocco's email to receive the Zoom link.



Have a lovely weekend!

Paul

Hooray! We'll send an acceptance letter to the author - Daniel Hulsebosch - from NYU. We would also love to invite him, and we can send him the same invitation you used earlier in the year.

 

In other news, our Masthead is also eager to attend, and we will send them Karen Crocco's email to receive the Zoom link.

 

Have a lovely weekend!

Paul

I have just finished reading the review again. It is excellent. I very much admire the content and the writing style. I agree with everything he/she says.

It will be wonderful to have the piece in the issue.



Question: Do you think it is appropriate to have the person participate in the symposium?  Are you able, now, to reveal the name?

Thank you,

Claire

Subject: Symposium Article to Review



Hello Prof. Priest,



I hope you've enjoyed your weekend. There are so few left before the school year, and I can't believe classes (and the symposium!) are right around the corner. If you have time this week, we would love to have your feedback on the attached Credit Nation book review that was submitted for the Symposium Issue. We thought it deserved your review given the amount of primary/secondary resources the author pulls on to comment on and supplement your book. So far, we have no other articles ready for the issue, though Prof. Berger is working on a piece for us thanks to your suggestion. Perhaps this book review will be a solid foundation to build around.



We're looking forward to meeting you in person, and we wish you a lovely end to your summer!



Best,

Paul & Greg

"

Re: Credit Nation Symposium Comments - Please confirm receipt,"Paul (if I may),


Good evening.

I have enclosed ""Caribbean Credit Nations."" Given the deadline, I thought it best to send it to you now. Please confirm receipt.

Unfortunately, I was unable to put in the footnotes. Because I work with Lutie (which builds a pipeline of Black women who are aspiring law professors), I am involved with mooting candidates. For this reason, the last few days have been very hectic.  With apologies - I must now go again to a Lutie obligation and we will undoubtedly run late.

I am asking for permission to send you a revised version with footnotes over the weekend.  I have also taken the liberty of attaching my c.v. since this is sometimes requested by journals.

Thank you for your kind consideration.

Best,

EMB


Eleanor Brown (202 361 5568/ 786 201 3823)

Professor of Law and International Affairs

Senior Scientist, the Rock Ethics Institute

The Pennsylvania State University,

Immediate Past Chair, Lutie Lytle Black Women Law Faculty Conference

Hello everyone,

This is just a friendly reminder to send your comments to yjlh@yale.edu by next Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. We look forward to reading your thoughts!

subject: Credit Nation Symposium Comments

recipients.name: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities

body:
Good morning all,

My name is Paul, and along with Greg, I am one of the Editors-in-Chief of the Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities. As you are aware, we are working with Prof. Priest to publish an issue on the Credit Nation Symposium, and we would love to include your comments.

We are not imposing a page limit, but we expect most comments to have no more than ten pages. We also recognize that not everyone will be familiar with our Bluebook citation style, and so we only ask that you use footnotes rather than in-text citations. We do prefer Chicago over any other non-Bluebook style, but given our journal's broad coverage, we're pretty familiar with it all.

To meet our publishing deadline, we ask that first drafts for all comments be sent to yjlh@yale.edu <mailto:yjlh@yale.edu>  no later than Friday, October 15th, at 11:59PM. Once we receive your comment, we will assign you an Articles Editor to work on revisions and any sourceciting that is required.

We look forward to working with you this fall!

Sincerely,
Paul

Gregory Antill & Paul Meosky

Editors-in-Chief
Yale Journal of Law & the Humanities
yjlh@yale.edu
"

Re: Symposium Article to Review,"Paul,

You should know that I sent the schedule to Dan and a number of colleagues and friends yesterday, not knowing he had written that piece.



Before inviting him to take part in the conference, I’d like to touch base with Taisu and also hear back from the other panelists to see where things are.

So let’s not invite him just yet. By Monday we will have a lot more information.

I think the invitation should come from Taisu—if it is ok with you—since Taisu invited the others.



You could accept the piece now and either resend the schedule or not. We’ll be in touch with him next week if there is room on a panel.

Thank you,

Claire



From: ""Meosky, Paul"" <paul.meosky@yale.edu>
Date: Friday, August 27, 2021 at 11:36 AM
To: ""Priest, Claire"" <claire.priest@yale.edu>
Cc: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities <yjlh@yale.edu>, ""Antill, Gregory"" <gregory.antill@yale.edu>
Subject: Re: Symposium Article to Review



Hello Claire,



I have the acceptance ready to send to Prof. Hulsebosch, but I wasn't sure what role you'd like him to play in the symposium. Should I just send him the date for now? Or would you like me to ask him to participate in any of the panels? I can also just ask him to RSVP directly to you, and you can discuss possibilities at that time. Please let me know what you'd prefer.



Best,

Paul

body:
Fantastic!

I was wondering who could write such an eloquent informed piece, with an emphasis on loyalists. I thought of Dan but then he tricked me with how he sighted his work in the piece. I’m proud to have him in the issue with the conference papers!

Now I’m wondering if we should include him in the author meets readers panel . . . .





From: ""Meosky, Paul"" <paul.meosky@yale.edu>
Date: Friday, August 27, 2021 at 9:27 AM
To: ""Priest, Claire"" <claire.priest@yale.edu>
Cc: Yale Journal of Law and Humanities <yjlh@yale.edu>, ""Antill, Gregory"" <gregory.antill@yale.edu>
Subject: Re: Symposium Article to Review



Good morning Claire,



Hooray! We'll send an acceptance letter to the author - Daniel Hulsebosch - from NYU. We would also love to invite him, and we can send him the same invitation you used earlier in the year.



In other news, our Masthead is also eager to attend, and we will send them Karen Crocco's email to receive the Zoom link.



Have a lovely weekend!

Paul

Hello Prof. Priest,



I hope you've enjoyed your weekend. There are so few left before the school year, and I can't believe classes (and the symposium!) are right around the corner. If you have time this week, we would love to have your feedback on the attached Credit Nation book review that was submitted for the Symposium Issue. We thought it deserved your review given the amount of primary/secondary resources the author pulls on to comment on and supplement your book. So far, we have no other articles ready for the issue, though Prof. Berger is working on a piece for us thanks to your suggestion. Perhaps this book review will be a solid foundation to build around.



We're looking forward to meeting you in person, and we wish you a lovely end to your summer!



Best,

Paul & Greg
